verses.verse: (2 One lying at the pool,5 is healed of Christ on the Sabbath.10 The Jews that rashly find fault with that his deed,17 he convinceth with the authority of his Father, 19, 20 He proveth his divine power by many reasons,45 and with Moses’ testimony.) After (Cross references: : Lev. 23:3; Deut. 16:1) that, there was a feast of the Jews, and Jesus went to Jerusalem.

(There is no disease so old, which Christ cannot heal.) And there is at Jerusalem by the place of the sheep, a (Whereof cattle drank, and used to be plunged in; whereof there could not be but great store at Jerusalem.) pool called in Hebrew (That is to say, the house of pouring out, because great store of water was poured out into that place.) Bethesda, having five porches:
In the which lay a great multitude of sick folk, of blind, halt, and withered, waiting for the moving of the water.
For an Angel went down at a certain season into the pool, and troubled the water: whosoever then first, after the stirring of the water, stepped in, was made whole of whatsoever disease he had.
And a certain man was there, which had been diseased eight and thirty years.
When Jesus saw him lie, and knew that he now long time had been diseased, he said unto him, Wilt thou be made whole?
The sick man answered him, Sir, I have no man, when the water is troubled, to put me into the pool: but while I am coming, another steppeth down before me.
Jesus said unto him, Rise: take up thy bed, and walk.
And immediately the man was made whole, and took up his bed, and walked: and the same day was the Sabbath.

(True religion is no more cruelly assaulted by any means, than by the pretence of religion itself.) The Jews therefore said to him that was made whole, It is the Sabbath day: (Jer. 17:22) it is not lawful for thee to carry thy bed.
He answered them, He that made me whole he said unto me, Take up thy bed, and walk.
Then asked they him, What man is that which said unto thee, Take up thy bed, and walk?
And he that was healed, knew not who it was: for Jesus had conveyed himself away from the multitude that was in that place.
And after that, Jesus found him in the Temple, and said unto him, Behold, thou art made whole: sin no more, lest a worse thing come unto thee.
¶ The man departed, and told the Jews that it was Jesus that had made him whole.
And therefore the Jews did persecute Jesus, and sought to slay him, because he had done these things on the Sabbath day.

(The work of God was never the breach of the Sabbath: but the works of Christ are the works of the Father, both because they are one God, and also because the Father doth not work but in the Son.) But Jesus answered them, My father worketh hitherto, and I work.

(John 7:19) Therefore the Jews sought the more to kill him: not only because he had broken the Sabbath: but said also that God was (That is, his only and no man’s else, which they gather by that, that he saith, (And I work) applying this word (work) to himself, which is proper to God, and therefore maketh himself equal to God.) his Father, and made himself equal with God.

Then answered Jesus, and said unto them, Verily, verily I say unto you, The Son can do nothing (Not only without his Father’s authority, but also without his mighty working and power.) of himself, save that he (This must be understood of Christ’s person, which consisteth of two natures, and not simply of his Godhead: so then he saith that his Father moveth and governeth him in all things, but yet notwithstanding, when he saith he worketh with his Father, he voucheth his Godhead.) seeth the Father do: for whatsoever things he doeth, the same things doeth the Son (In like sort, jointly and together. Not for that the Father doeth some things, and then the son worketh after him, and doeth the like, but because the might and power of the Father and the Son do work equally and jointly together.) in like manner.
For the Father loveth the Son, and showeth him all things, whatsoever he himself doeth, and he will show him greater works than these, that ye should marvel.

(The Father maketh no man partaker of everlasting life, but in Christ, in whom only also he is truly worshipped.) For likewise as the Father raiseth up the dead, and quickeneth them, so the Son quickeneth whom he will.

For the Father (This word (judgeth) is taken by the figure Synecdoche, for all government.) judgeth (These words are not so to be taken, as though they simply denied that God governeth the world, but as the Jews imagined it, which separate the Father from the Son, whereas indeed, the Father doth not govern the world but only in the person of his Son, being made manifest in the flesh: so saith he afterward, verse 30, that he came not to do his own will: that his doctrine is not his own, John 7:16, that the blind man and his parents sinned not, etc., John 9:3.) no man, but hath committed all judgment unto the Son,
Because that all men should honor the Son, as they honor the Father: he that honoreth not the Son, the same honoreth not the Father which hath sent him.

(The Father is not worshipped but by his Son’s word apprehended by faith, which is the only way that leadeth to eternal life.) Verily, verily I say unto you, he that heareth my word, and believeth him that sent me, hath everlasting life, and shall not come into condemnation, but hath passed from death to life.

(We are all dead in sin and cannot be quickened by any other means, than by the word of Christ apprehended by faith.) Verily, verily I say unto you, the hour shall come, and now is, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God: and they that hear it shall live.
For as the Father hath life in himself, so likewise hath he given to the Son to have life in himself.

And hath given him (That is, high and sovereign power to rule and govern all things, insomuch that he hath power of life and death.) power also to execute judgment, in that he is the (That is, he shall not only judge the world as he is God, but also as he is man, he received this of his Father to be judge of the world.) Son of man.
(All shall appear before the judgment seat of Christ at length to be judged.) Marvel not at this: for the hour shall come, in the which all that are in the graves, shall hear his voice.

(Faith and infidelity shall be judged by their fruits.) And they shall come (Of their graves.) forth, (Matt. 25:41) that have done good, unto the (To that resurrection which had life everlasting following it: against which is set the resurrection of condemnation: that is, which condemnation followeth.) resurrection of life: but they that have done evil, unto the resurrection of condemnation.

(The father is the author and approver of all things which Christ doeth.) I can (See verse 22.) do nothing of mine own self: (As my father directeth me, who dwelleth in me.) as I hear, I judge: and my judgment is just, because I seek not mine own will, but the will of the Father who hath sent me.
If I (John 8:14) should bear witness of myself, my witness were not (Faithful, that is, worthy to be credited, see John 8:14.) true.
(Matt. 3:17) There is another that beareth witness of me, and I know that the witness, which he beareth of me, is true.

(John 1:27) (Christ is declared to be the only Savior by John’s voice, and infinite miracles, and by the testimonies of all the Prophets. But the world notwithstanding being addicted to false prophets, and desirous to seem religious, seeth none of all these things.) Ye sent unto John, and he bore witness unto the truth.
But I receive not the record of man: nevertheless these things I say, that ye might be saved.
He was a burning and a shining candle: and ye would for (A little while.) a season have rejoiced in his light.
But I have greater witness than the witness of John: for the works which the Father hath given me to finish, the same works that I do, bear witness of me, that the Father sent me.
And the (Matt. 3:15; Matt. 17:5) Father himself, which hath sent me, beareth witness of me. Ye have not heard his voice at any time, (Deut. 4:12) neither have ye seen his shape.
And his word have you not abiding in you: for whom he hath sent, him ye believed not.
(Acts 17:11) Search the Scriptures: for in them ye think to have eternal life, and they are they which testify of me.
But ye will not come to me, that ye might have life.
I receive not the praise of men.
But I know you, that ye have not the (Love toward God.) love of God in you.
I am come in my Father’s Name, and ye receive me not: if another shall come in his own name, him will ye receive.
How can ye believe, which receive (John 12:43) honor one of another, and seek not the honor that cometh of God alone?

(This denial doth not put away that which is here said, but correcteth it, as if Christ said, the Jews shall have no sorer an accuser than Moses.) Do not think that I will accuse you to my Father: there is one that accuseth you, even Moses, in whom ye trust.
For had ye believed Moses, ye would have believed me: for he (Gen. 3:15; Gen. 22:18; Gen 49:10; Deut. 18:15) wrote of me.
But if ye believe not his writings, how shall ye believe my words.
